definitions.definition: Darkness where light, particularly sunlight, is blocked.
definitions.example: The old oak tree gave shade in the heat of the day.

definitions.definition: Something that blocks light, particularly in a window.
definitions.example: Close the shade, please: it's too bright in here.

definitions.definition: A variety of a colour/color, in particular one obtained by adding black (compare tint).
definitions.example: I've painted my room in five lovely shades of pink and chartreuse.

definitions.definition: A subtle variation in a concept.
An aspect that is reminiscent of something.
A very small degree of a quantity, or variety of meaning
A ghost or specter; a spirit.
definitions.example: The adventurer was attacked by a shade.

definitions.definition: A postage stamp showing an obvious difference in colour/color to the original printing and needing a separate catalogue/catalog entry.

definitions.example: Why did you paint your room chartreuse? No shade; I'm genuinely curious.
The old oak tree shaded the lawn in the heat of the day.
Most politicians will shade the truth if it helps them.

definitions.definition: To vary or approach something slightly, particularly in color.
definitions.example: The hillside was bright green, shading towards gold in the drier areas.

definitions.definition: (of a defensive player) To move slightly from one's normal fielding position.
definitions.example: Jones will shade a little to the right on this pitch count.
I draw contours first, gradually shading in midtones and shadows.

definitions.definition: To surpass by a narrow margin.
definitions.example: Both parties claimed afterwards that their man did best in the debate, but an early opinion poll suggested Mr Cameron shaded it.

definitions.definition: To reduce (a window) so that only its title bar is visible.
To shelter; to cover from injury; to protect; to screen.
To present a shadow or image of; to shadow forth; to represent.

definitions.example: His shades are by some famous designer.
